abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Drought
            Recovery Project of Zambia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) Bank
            assistance should pay particular attention to food security
            issues in countries with chronic food insecurity and
            vulnerability to natural disasters; 2) To address food
            insecurity a regional approach which promoted regional trade
            is needed; 3) It is essential to the success of a public
            works project to establish apriority objective of public
            works between quick income generation and creation and/or
            rehabilitation of assets with an acceptable technical
            standard. An appropriate timing of public works is also
            imperative to avert conflicting labor demand for
            agriculture; and 4) Careful selection of institutional
            arrangements to implement emergency operations would allow a
            quick project start-up and minimize implementation risks.

8147064.trustfund: TF020820-AGRICULTURE RESEARCH & EXTENSION,TF053034-RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT,TFM20820-AGRICULTURE RESEARCH & EXTENSION,TFM53034-RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT,TFS20820-AGRICULTURE RESEARCH & EXTENSION,TFS53034-RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objectives of the Emergency
            Drought Recovery Project (EDRP) for Zambia were to assist
            the government in maintaining key commitments to its
            economic and investment priorities as laid out in the
            Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) while meeting the
            exigencies of the food crisis, and to help restore
            productive capability of the affected population. The
            development objective was not revised during project
            implementation. Principal performance ratings are as
            follows: project outcome was satisfactory; sustainability
            was likely; institutional development impact was modest; and
            Bank and borrower performance was satisfactory. A number of
            lessons have been derived from the project and, it is hoped,
            will be learned by both the Bank and its borrowers. Some of
            the lessons learned are: The EDRP aimed at incorporating
            lessons learned from previous emergency projects, such as
            ' emergency operations must be simple and rapidly
            executable, and not undertake too broad an agenda of
            cross-cutting issues ', ' speed in implementation
            is a critical element of success '. These lessons
            remain valid, but they were not practiced during EDRP
            implementation. 2) Short term and long term objectives
            should not be combined in one lending instrument. 3) The
            Bank needs to apply its disbursement and procurement
            guidelines more flexibly in future emergency operations in
            order to adequately meet the urgent needs of the client, 4)
            Appropriate outcome-orientated monitoring and evaluation
            indicators must be identified at appraisal, even in an
            emergency operation when project preparation time is
            limited. The PIU was charged with identifying additional
            project performance indicators, but ultimately failed to
            complete the task. 5) Finally, the implementation of a
            multi-sectoral project such as the EDRP, should be
            complemented by multi-sectoral donor coordination to avoid
            duplication and inconsistencies.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objectives of the Emergency
            Drought Recovery Project are to assist the Zambian
            Government to maintain key commitments to its economic and
            investment priorities laid out in the Poverty Reduction
            Strategy Paper (PRSP) while meeting the exigencies of the
            food crisis, and to help restore the productive capability
            of the affected people. The project consists of four
            components: 1) quick-disbursing assistance to finance a
            positive list of imports; 2) safety net interventions aimed
            at improving access to food and services by vulnerable
            groups; 3) distribution of agricultural inputs and
            technologies to help farmers restart agriculture; and 4)
            strengthening government's early warning system and
            capacity for disaster mitigation and management. Benefits
            include reducing the hardship caused by the food emergency,
            while helping to maintain investments in health, education,
            and rural infrastructure. The project will enhance the
            capacity of vulnerable groups to access goods and services
            by providing temporary employment and income supplements
            through public works and other targeted interventions. Risks
            derive from limitations in the capacity of the government to
            handle complex issues related to the logistics and
            distribution of food and other critical supplies to
            vulnerable people.
